title: 109_hr2050
content: The Act may be cited as the "Old Man of the Mountain Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that the Old Man of the Mountain, a granite cliff formation in New Hampshire, symbolizes the state's independence and traditions. The profile of the Old Man delighted all who saw it and represented New Hampshire's love of liberty. The rocky ledges that formed the Old Man eventually collapsed, ending its steadfast defiance of gravity. The Old Man of the Mountain, a symbol of New Hampshire's independence and traditions, collapsed on May 3, 2003, forever changing the landscape. A commemorative coin will immortalize the Old Man's watchful gaze and help finance a suitable memorial. The commemorative coin will immortalize the Old Man of the Mountain's watchful gaze and help finance a suitable memorial. SEC. 3 outlines the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. According to title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items. Design of coins under this Act will be considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the Old Man of the Mountain, with inscriptions including the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". Numismatic design features like reverse proofing or raised lettering on the edge will be used. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Old Man of the Mountain Revitalization Fund, Inc., and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. The design may include raised lettering on the edge of the coin and other unique numismatic design features determined by the Secretary. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility starting January 1, 2008, with minting ending on December 31, 2008. SEC. 6 of the Act outlines the sale of coins, including pricing details and bulk sales. The Secretary will sell coins at face value plus a surcharge and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. SEC. 7 of the Act specifies surcharges for coins minted under this Act: $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Old Man of the Mountain Revitalization Fund, Inc. for its purposes. The Fund will be audited as per the requirements of title 31, United States Code.
